case_name: Akalu Ahir, Chandrika Singh and Jagarnath v. Ramdeo Ram

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 40 of 1970 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 14, 1969 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 190 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 40 of 1970. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order October 14, 1969 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 190 of 1969.

facts.text: The three appellants and one Ramchander Kanu were tried in the court of the 2nd Assistant Sessions Judge, Chopra for offences under ss. 307 and 307/109, I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: The three appellants and one Ramehander Kanu were tried in the companyrt of the 2nd Assistant Sessions Judge, Chopra for offences under ss. 307 and 307/ 109, I.P.C.

facts.text: Akalu Ahir and Chandrika Singh were charged under s. 307 I.P.C. for firing pistol shots and gun shots at Ramdeo Ram at 11.00 p.m. on June 13, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Akalu Ahir and Chandrika Singh were charged under s. 307 I.P.C. for firing pistol shots and gun shots at Ramdeo Ram at 11.00 p.m. on June 13, 1966, whereas Jagarnath and Ramchander Kanu were charged under ss. 307/109 I.P.C.

facts.text: Jagarnath and Ramchander Kanu were charged under ss. 307/109 I.P.C. for having abetted the commission of the offence.

anchor.surface_text: whereas Jagarnath and Ramchander Kanu were charged under ss. 307/109 I.P.C. for having abetted the companymission of the aforesaid offence. The occurrence is stated to be an off-shoot of election rivalry arising out of the election for the office of Mukhia of village Arakpur.

facts.text: The occurrence is an off-shoot of election rivalry arising out of the election for the office of Mukhia of village Arakpur.

anchor.surface_text: The occurrence is stated to be an off-shoot of election rivalry arising out of the election for the office of Mukhia of village Arakpur. Indeed the enmity between the two rival groups was of long standing and is number denied.

facts.text: Enmity between the two rival groups was of long standing and is not denied.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed the enmity between the two rival groups was of long standing and is number denied. But enmity as usual is a double-edged weapon, providing motive both for the offence as well as for false implication.

facts.text: There were three eye witnesses: Ramdeo Ram (P.W. 1), Puljharia (P.W. 9) and Ploughman Bhuidhar Chamar (P.W. 10).

anchor.surface_text: In this case there were three eye witnesses. Ramdeo Ram, the victim of the fire shots, appeared as P. W. 1. Puljharia as P. W. 9 and Ploughman Bhuidhar Chamar as P.W. 10.

facts.text: The trial Judge felt no doubt that Ramdeo Ram had been injured by gun shots.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge after companysidering the evidence on the. record felt numberdoubt about the-fact that Ramdeo Ram had been injured by gun shots, but he did number feel impressed by the prosecution evidence

facts.text: The trial Judge acquitted the accused persons as prosecution failed to prove charges beyond reasonable doubt.

anchor.surface_text: with respect to the manner in which the occurrence had taken place, with the result that in his opinion, the prosecution had number been able to prove the charges against the accused persons beyond reasonable doubt.

facts.text: The State did not file any appeal against the order of acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The State did number file any appeal against the order of acquittal. Ramdeo Ram, the victim of the gun shots, however, presented in the High Court in January, 1969 a revision petition

facts.text: Ramdeo Ram presented a revision petition in the High Court in January 1969 under ss. 435 and 439, Cr.P.C. against the acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: Ramdeo Ram, the victim of the gun shots, however, presented in the High Court in January, 1969 a revision petition under ss. 435 and 439, Cr.P.C. from the order acquitting the four accused persons.

facts.text: The name of Jagarnath Kanu was expunged from the array of respondents in the revision by court's order dated July 3, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Prom a numbere on the printed application for revision, it appears that the name of Jagarnath Kanu was expunged from the array of respondents in the revision vide, companyrts order dated July 3, 1969.

facts.text: The High Court allowed the revision petition, set aside the acquittal and ordered re-trial.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, quashed the High Court order and restored the trial court's order.

holdings.text: The High Court committed a serious error in directing re-trial on the basis of its reassessment of the oral evidence on the record while exercising its power of revision at the instance of a private complainant.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the foregoing discussions, in our opinion, the High Court had committed a serious error in directing re- trial on the basis of its reassessment of the oral evidence on the record, while exercising its power of revision at the instance of a private, complainant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court reweighed evidence instead of checking for glaring legal defects, contrary to limits under ss.435/439 CrPC and precedents like K.C. Reddy.

holdings.text: A court of revision is not justified in examining the evidence as if it was a court of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: It was further contended that as a court of revision, the High Court was not justified in examining the evidence as if it was a court of appeal and was, as such, required to see if the evidence had been correctly appraised by the trial-court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revisional jurisdiction under s.439 does not permit full appellate re-appraisal of evidence, especially against acquittal; confirmed by ss.417, 439(5) and precedents.

holdings.text: The order directing re-trial on the facts and circumstances of this case was not justified.

holdings.text: The present case is not an exceptional case warranting interference by the High Court in revision against acquittal by re-appraising evidence and ordering re-trial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.439(5) prohibits revision where appeal lies; cannot indirectly convict via re-trial; statutory scheme favors finality in acquittals unless grave injustice.

holdings.text: High Court in revision against acquittal by private party must refrain from interfering except in cases of glaring legal defect resulting in grave failure of justice.

anchor.surface_text: Considering the problem facing the Court in this case in the background of this scheme, the High Court when approached by a private party for exercising its power of revision from an order of acquittal, should appropriately refrain from interfering except when there is a glaring legal defect of a serious nature which has resulted in grave failure, of justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extraordinary discretionary power under ss.435/439 for justice, not routine re-appraisal; guided by tradition, analogy, precedents like Amar Chand.

holdings.text: Revisional jurisdiction under s.439 CrPC is not to be lightly exercised by private party against acquittal when State has right of appeal under s.417.

anchor.surface_text: As observed in D. Stephens case supra , the revisional jurisdiction under S. 439, Cr.P.C. is not to be lightly exercised when invoked by a private party against an order of acquittal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preserves statutory scheme limiting acquittal appeals primarily to State; private revision subordinate and exceptional.

holdings.text: Illustrative categories justifying High Court interference with acquittal in revision: lack of jurisdiction, shutting out evidence, wrongly holding evidence inadmissible, overlooking material evidence, invalid compounding.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed, the impugned order of the High Court is quashed and the order of the trial court is restored.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, constrained to allow this appeal, quash the impugned order of the High Court and restore that of the trial court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of revisional limits to facts; restores acquittal as no exceptional grounds found.

Considering the problem facing the Court in this case in the background of this scheme, the High Court when approached by a private party for exercising its power of revision from an order of acquittal, should appropriately refrain from interfering except when there is a glaring legal defect of a serious nature which has resulted in grave failure, of justice.
As observed in D. Stephens case supra , the revisional jurisdiction under S. 439, Cr.P.C. is not to be lightly exercised when invoked by a private party against an order of acquittal
